title: How to Prepare Dum Aloo

steps.headline: Pre-cook the potatoes.
steps.description: Wash the baby potatoes well to remove all dirt, then wipe them dry. If the potatoes are small, leave them whole. If they're larger, cut them in halves or quarters. Par-boil the potatoes so that they are somewhat cooked, but not completely cooked. This should take 6 to 7 minutes. Drain the potatoes and wipe them dry. Prick them all over with a fork. Peel the potatoes when they're cool enough to handle.

steps.headline: Fry the potatoes.
steps.description: Heat your oil in a deep fryer or shallow skillet over medium-high heat. Add the potatoes and fry them until they're completely cooked. Remove them and set aside. Test the potatoes for doneness by sticking a fork or knife through the center of a potato. It should easily slide through, offering no resistance.

steps.headline: Cook your spices.
steps.description: In a large skillet, heat 2 tablespoons of oil over medium-high heat and add the caraway seeds. Cook until they start to sizzle in the oil. Reduce the heat to medium and add the asafoetida, fennel powder, and chili powder, stirring well. Add 2 tablespoons of water and let the spices cook for a minute.

steps.headline: Add the curd or yogurt.
steps.description: Stir or whisk the curd or yogurt into your mixture until no lumps remain. Let the mixture start to boil.

steps.headline: Add your remaining spices and potatoes.
steps.description: Add the whole cardamom, cinnamon stick, cloves, black peppercorns, ginger powder, fennel powder, fried potatoes, water, and salt. Stir the mixture well.

steps.headline: Cook the mixture.
steps.description: Cover the mixture with a lid and let it simmer, or gently bubble, for 10 to 15 minutes. The mixture should start to thicken up into a gravy.

steps.headline: Garnish and serve.
steps.description: Sprinkle extra caraway seeds on top as a garnish and serve along with rice, rotis, or naan.

steps.headline: Pre-cook the potatoes.
steps.description: Wash the baby potatoes well to remove all dirt, then wipe them dry. If the potatoes are small, leave them whole. If they're larger, cut them in halves or quarters. Heat your oil in a deep fryer or shallow skillet over medium heat. Add the potatoes and fry until completely cooked. Test the potatoes for doneness by sticking a fork or knife through the center of a potato. It should easily slide through, offering no resistance.

steps.headline: Make a cashew paste.
steps.description: Take your soaked cashews and soaking water and blend them in a food processor until the cashews blend into a paste. Set this mixture aside.

steps.headline: Make an onion-spice paste.
steps.description: Place your onion, ginger, and garlic into a food processor and blend until the ingredients are completely smooth. Set this mixture aside for a moment.

steps.headline: Make tomato puree.
steps.description: Blend your tomato in a food processor until it's completely smooth and pureed. Set the tomato puree aside for a moment.

steps.headline: Heat your spices.
steps.description: In a large skillet, heat 2 to 3 tablespoons of cooking or mustard oil over medium-high heat. When the oil is hot and shimmering, add the black cardamom and cinnamon stick. When it smells fragrant, add your onion-spice paste.

steps.headline: Cook the onion-spice paste.
steps.description: Reduce the heat to medium and cook the onion-spice paste in your fragrant oil until it becomes golden brown and the oil starts separating on the surface. This should take 9 to 10 minutes. If you notice the onions turning brown very quickly or beginning to burn, reduce the heat even more and let it cook slower.

steps.headline: Add the tomato puree.
steps.description: Carefully stir in your tomato puree. Use caution as it may sputter a bit. Let the mixture keep cooking for another 3 to 4 minutes.

steps.headline: Add dry spices and continue to cook.
steps.description: Add the turmeric powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, garam masala powder, and fennel powder. Stir well and keep cooking over medium heat until the oil starts to separate or pull away from the sides of the skillet. This should take 10 to 12 minutes.

steps.headline: Add the cashew paste and yogurt, if you're using it.
steps.description: Stir the cashew paste and optional yogurt until they're well combined. Keep cooking the mixture until the oil separates again, about 3 to 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Add water.
steps.description: Add 2.5 to 3 cups of water to the mixture and stir well. This will keep the mixture from sticking to the bottom of the pan when you add your potatoes.

steps.headline: Add the cooked potatoes.
steps.description: Stir in your fried potatoes and let them simmer in the gravy mixture for 4 to 5 minutes. The mixture will begin to thicken up.

steps.headline: Add final seasonings and garnish.
steps.description: If you didn't add yogurt earlier, stir in the lemon juice. Add the salt and stir to combine the mixture. Garnish with chopped cilantro/coriander leaves and serve with rotis or rice.

text: For Kashmiri Dum Aloo Pre-cook the potatoes. Wash the baby potatoes well to remove all dirt, then wipe them dry. If the potatoes are small, leave them whole. If they're larger, cut them in halves or quarters. Par-boil the potatoes so that they are somewhat cooked, but not completely cooked. This should take 6 to 7 minutes. Drain the potatoes and wipe them dry. Prick them all over with a fork. Peel the potatoes when they're cool enough to handle. Fry the potatoes. Heat your oil in a deep fryer or shallow skillet over medium-high heat. Add the potatoes and fry them until they're completely cooked. Remove them and set aside. Test the potatoes for doneness by sticking a fork or knife through the center of a potato. It should easily slide through, offering no resistance. Cook your spices. In a large skillet, heat 2 tablespoons of oil over medium-high heat and add the caraway seeds. Cook until they start to sizzle in the oil. Reduce the heat to medium and add the asafoetida, fennel powder, and chili powder, stirring well. Add 2 tablespoons of water and let the spices cook for a minute. Add the curd or yogurt. Stir or whisk the curd or yogurt into your mixture until no lumps remain. Let the mixture start to boil. Add your remaining spices and potatoes. Add the whole cardamom, cinnamon stick, cloves, black peppercorns, ginger powder, fennel powder, fried potatoes, water, and salt. Stir the mixture well. Cook the mixture. Cover the mixture with a lid and let it simmer, or gently bubble, for 10 to 15 minutes. The mixture should start to thicken up into a gravy. Garnish and serve. Sprinkle extra caraway seeds on top as a garnish and serve along with rice, rotis, or naan. For Punjabi Dum Aloo Pre-cook the potatoes. Wash the baby potatoes well to remove all dirt, then wipe them dry. If the potatoes are small, leave them whole. If they're larger, cut them in halves or quarters. Heat your oil in a deep fryer or shallow skillet over medium heat. Add the potatoes and fry until completely cooked. Test the potatoes for doneness by sticking a fork or knife through the center of a potato. It should easily slide through, offering no resistance. Make a cashew paste. Take your soaked cashews and soaking water and blend them in a food processor until the cashews blend into a paste. Set this mixture aside. Make an onion-spice paste. Place your onion, ginger, and garlic into a food processor and blend until the ingredients are completely smooth. Set this mixture aside for a moment. Make tomato puree. Blend your tomato in a food processor until it's completely smooth and pureed. Set the tomato puree aside for a moment. Heat your spices. In a large skillet, heat 2 to 3 tablespoons of cooking or mustard oil over medium-high heat. When the oil is hot and shimmering, add the black cardamom and cinnamon stick. When it smells fragrant, add your onion-spice paste. Cook the onion-spice paste. Reduce the heat to medium and cook the onion-spice paste in your fragrant oil until it becomes golden brown and the oil starts separating on the surface. This should take 9 to 10 minutes. If you notice the onions turning brown very quickly or beginning to burn, reduce the heat even more and let it cook slower. Add the tomato puree. Carefully stir in your tomato puree. Use caution as it may sputter a bit. Let the mixture keep cooking for another 3 to 4 minutes. Add dry spices and continue to cook. Add the turmeric powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, garam masala powder, and fennel powder. Stir well and keep cooking over medium heat until the oil starts to separate or pull away from the sides of the skillet. This should take 10 to 12 minutes. Add the cashew paste and yogurt, if you're using it. Stir the cashew paste and optional yogurt until they're well combined. Keep cooking the mixture until the oil separates again, about 3 to 5 minutes. Add water. Add 2.5 to 3 cups of water to the mixture and stir well. This will keep the mixture from sticking to the bottom of the pan when you add your potatoes. Add the cooked potatoes. Stir in your fried potatoes and let them simmer in the gravy mixture for 4 to 5 minutes. The mixture will begin to thicken up. Add final seasonings and garnish. If you didn't add yogurt earlier, stir in the lemon juice. Add the salt and stir to combine the mixture. Garnish with chopped cilantro/coriander leaves and serve with rotis or rice.
